p: Following the above discovery, the same authors in two independent studies demonstrated that silymarin treatment blocked different steps of the HCV (JFH-1) life cycle, including entry/fusion, replication, and virion production in the host cells [ 9, 10]. Furthermore, silymarin and its derived pure compounds exhibited potent hepatoprotective functions by inhibiting the HCV-induced oxidative stress, NFκB-dependent transcription, and T-cell receptor (TCR)-mediated proliferation [ 9]. Interestingly, both studies observed an impact of silymarin on HCV NS5B RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) activity, albeit at concentrations higher than that required for its anti-HCV effect. Consistent with the inhibition of the RdRp activity, Belkacem et al. employing silybin A, silybin B, and Legalon ® SIL demonstrated that all three forms of silymarin components inhibited HCV replication by targeting the HCV RdRp activity of NS5B, with an IC50 value ranging between 75–100 μM [ 11].
